citeinfo.title: Aleutian Arc geothermal fluids: chemical analyses of waters and gases (2015)

descript.abstract: This report contains the chemical and isotopic data from thermal waters and gases collected from the Aleutian Arc over the past 20 years, where such data remain unpublished or only published in part.
descript.purpose: The data were collected for purposes such as constraining the strength of magmatic degassing, evaluating geothermal resources, or simply establishing baseline hydrologic conditions at remote volcanoes that are seldom visited.
descript.supplinfo: It is likely that most location information is referenced to WGS 84, but we cannot verify this.

idinfo.useconst: Please recognize the U.S. Geological Survey as the source of this information.

The determination of forty four elements in aqueous samples by inductively coupled plasma - mass spectrometry

procstep.procdesc: Gas samples discussed herein were collected in evacuated glass sample bottles without added caustic. Bubbling gases were collected from springs using an inverted funnel and water displacement. Fumarole gases were collected through a metal tube into a T-handle glass bottle with a downstream pinch clamp. Samples for dissolved inorganic carbon (DIC) and its isotopes were collected by injecting water into a septum-equipped evacuated glass bottle using a syringe. Helium isotope samples were collected in copper tubes sealed with refrigeration clamps.

Some water samples were collected according to established field protocols, including: on-site measurement of pH; filtration of water for chemical analysis through 0.45 mu-m membrane filters; acidification of cation samples; collection of isotope and alkalinity samples in tightly sealed glass bottles. However, for many of the water samples, field measurements were minimal and consist of temperature and location, and only raw (unfiltered) water samples were collected. Unless otherwise specified, the pH, specific conductance, and alkalinity values presented in the tables are laboratory measurements, and filtration as needed prior to chemical analysis was performed in the laboratory. Lack of field processing probably has minimal negative impact on conservative species like Na, Cl and most major ions, but trace and redox-sensitive species like Fe or nutrients like NO3 and PO4 may have large uncertainties. A few raw, acidified samples were collected, which can greatly influence the concentrations of many of the metal species.

Chemical analyses of gas and water samples were carried out at USGS laboratories in Menlo Park, California. Gases were analyzed by using gas chromatographs equipped with a thermal-conductivity detector. Water samples were analyzed for anions by ion chromatography except for HCO3, which was analyzed by titration and should be considered as total alkalinity as HCO3 in all tables attached to this report. Cations were analyzed by argon plasma optical-emission spectrometry, and the results given in mg/L and g/L.

For some samples, major cation and trace element concentrations were determined at the USGS Minerals Program laboratories in Denver, Colorado, by inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS). These results are usually given in ppm and ppb. Analytical results presented herein preserve the units of the reporting laboratory.

For low salinity waters, mg/L nearly equals ppm, and g/L nearly equals ppb. Stable isotope analyses of waters, steam, DIC, CO2, and CH4 were performed by mass spectrometry at the USGS Stable Isotope Laboratory in Reston, Virginia.

Noble-gas ratios were determined by mass spectrometry at the USGS Noble Gas Laboratory in Denver, Colorado. Reported 3He/4He ratios are corrected for air contamination and are given as RC/RA values, where RA is the 3He/4He ratio in air.

overview.eaover: Explanation of data entries by individual column (9999 means no data; 8888 means that result was below detection limit): Name of volcano, volcanic center, or island where sampling occurred Sample number assigned by collector Brief description of feature sampled Type of fluid sampled; water, gas, or both Date of sampling Latitude in decimal degrees (WGS 84 datum for samples collected after 1990) Longitude in decimal degrees (WGS 84 datum for samples collected after 1990) Elevation of sample site in meters above sea level Temperature of feature in degrees Celsius Specific conductance of water in microSeimens/cm referenced to 25 degrees Celsius pH of water Location of pH measurement: in the field (on-site); in the lab (stored sample); or at a location described in the reference (for published values) Location of USGS laboratory performing anion analysis: Menlo (Park); Denver; or at a location described in the reference (for published values) F concentration in water in milligrams per liter Cl concentration in water in milligrams per liter SO4 concentration in water in milligrams per liter Br concentration in water in milligrams per liter NO3 concentration acidified; RA is raw acidified; or as described in the reference (for published values) Location of USGS laboratory performing cation analysis: Menlo (Park); Denver; or at a location described in the distinfo.distliab: Unless otherwise stated, all data, metadata and related materials are considered to satisfy the quality standards relative to the purpose for which the data were collected. Although these data and associated metadata have been reviewed for accuracy and completeness and approved for release by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the display or utility of the data on any other system or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. Any use of trade, product, or firm names is for descriptive purposes only and does not imply endorsement by the U.S. Government.
